titleStmt.title: Exceeding true and happy newes from the Castle of Windsor. Declaring how severall troopes of dragooners have taken possession of the said castle, to keepe it for the use of the King ann [sic] Parliament. Likewise manifesting hov [sic] severall companies of horse and foot are raysed by authority of the high court of Parliament in Essex. Buckingham-shire. Surrey. Midlesex. Barke-shire. Hampshire. and other adjoyning counties. With a remarkeable passage concerning the Earle of VVarwicke, who came to towne, on Tuesday 18th of this present October. Also a declaration concerning the major of Worcester, who was brought to towne on Wednesday the 19.th of Octob. with a waggon laden with plate and money.

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 7 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 5 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

availability.p: To the extent possible under law, the Text Creation Partnership has waived all copyright and related or neighboring rights to this keyboarded and encoded edition of the work described above, according to the terms of the CC0 1.0 Public Domain Dedication (http://creativecommons.org/publicdomain/zero/1.0/). This waiver does not extend to any page images or other supplementary files associated with this work, which may be protected by copyright or other license restrictions. Please go to https://www.textcreationpartnership.org/ for more information about the project.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: EXCEEDING True and happy Newes from the CASTLE OF WINDSOR.
Declaring how ≈øeverall Troopes of Dragooners have taken po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the ≈øaid Ca≈øtle, to keepe it for the u≈øe of the King ann Parliament.

Likewi≈øe manife≈øting how ≈øeverall Companies of Hor≈øe and Foot are ray≈øed by Authority of the high Court of Parliament in
E≈ø≈øex.
Buckingham-≈øhire.
Surrey.
Midle≈øex.
Barke-≈øhire.
Hamp≈øhire. And other adjoyning Counties.
With a remarkeable pa≈øsage concerning the Earle of VVarwicke, who came to towne, on Tue≈øday 18.th of this pre≈øent October.
Al≈øo a Declaration concerning the Major of Worce≈øter, who was brought to towne on Wedne≈øday the 19.th of Octob. with a Waggon laden with Plate and Money.
London, Printed for T. Franklin. Octob. 20. 16 ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ .

div.head: Exceeding true & ioyfull Newes FROM Wind≈øor Ca≈øtle.

Declaring how ≈øeverall Troopes of Dr ‚Ä¢
gooners have taken po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the ≈øaid Ca≈øtle, for the King and Parliament.
div.p:
THe Kings Maje≈øty having altered his intention of ≈øtaying at Shrewsbury (as is conceived by the Per≈øwa≈øion of that Cavalero rout, which have de≈øtin'd all to ruin and de≈øtruction) hath lately bent his
cour≈øe toward London, being per≈øuaded that here he ≈øhall have more ‚Ä¢ id and a≈ø≈øi≈øtance, (as is pretended) then he hath yet obtained, this pretence of theirs hath drawne his Maje≈øty into this cour≈øe, although it is apparently manife≈øt that they march up to London with an intent to plunder it, and bring all to ruine and de≈øtruction, that ≈øtand well affected to the King and Parliament.

For the perfecting of which practice, they intended to draw to VVind≈øor, and to take Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Ca≈øtle, that being a place of greate≈øt ≈øtrength in this part of the Kingdome, by rea≈øon of the heigth and ≈øtrength, the Country lying under it, ≈øo that the Ca≈øtle can command it round about.

Could they have obtained this Ca≈øtle, they would there have fortified them≈øelves, till ≈øuch time as they could have gathered ≈øtrength, which having obtained, they then intended (as is generally thought) to have marched again≈øt London
that being their onely aime, but God which ≈øees the ≈øecrets of all hearts hath brought their practizes to light & made them apparent to the eye of the world, their intentions were di≈øcovered to the high Court of Parliament, who by Gods a≈ø≈øi≈øtance and direction have taken the mo≈øt ≈øpeedy and effectuall cour≈øe to prevent ≈øo great a mi≈øcheife.

For by the appointment of the Parliament, ≈øeverall well affected Gentlemen and valiant Religious Commanders are gone into E≈ø≈øex, Midle≈øex, Buckingham-≈øhire, Barke-≈øhire, Surrey, Hamp-≈øhire, and other adjoyning Counties, to rai≈øe ≈øeverall Troopes of Dragooners and Voluntiers, ≈øome of which are arrived already at VVind≈øor, and have taken po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Ca≈øtle, for the u≈øe of his Maje≈øty and Parliament, others are in their march towards VVind≈øor, where being arrived, they intend to fortefie them≈øelves, and to make out-workes, ≈øo that the Cavaliers have lo≈øt their labour.

The Countries are very ready to goe in this ≈øervice, and ≈øtand generally for the Parliament, becau≈øe they ≈øee that the Cavaliers plunder all the places they came at, taking and ≈øeizing Hor≈øe and all things which are portable, and if any one re≈øi≈øt, they pre≈øently burne their Hou≈øes, to the utter ruin and de≈øtruction of all tho≈øe that have dependance thereon.

The Cavaliers in their march toward London vi≈øited Coventry a ≈øecond time, but the City with≈øtood them valiantly, and by the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of the Country routed their whole Army, ≈øo that they were forced to retreat di≈øorderly, and every one make ≈øhift for him≈øelfe.
The Country makes head again≈øt them as they march, being forced to guard their Townes, which if they ≈øhould neglect, the Cavaliers would plunder.

They pay for nothing, but live all upon pillaging and theeving, therefore
it is our be≈øt cour≈øe not to tru≈øt to their mercy, for who≈øoever tryes them, ≈øhall find them like ≈øo many Juda≈ø≈øes, and the poore Prote≈øtants ≈øhall be handled by them like ≈øo many Publicans among theeves, if ever they ≈øhould get the uper hand, or gaine power to perfect their bloudy de≈øignes.
But God be thanked all their plots have been brought to light, for he hath confounded them in the performance of all their ≈øecret De≈øignes.

div.head: A true Declaration of the particular cau≈øes of the Earle of Warwicks comming to London.
div.p:
THe Earle of Warwicke having received a command from the High Court of Parliament, intimating unto him, that it was their de≈øire that he ≈øhould re≈øigne his charge (during his ab≈øence) to his Vics-Admirall, and immediately repaire to London, which me≈ø≈øage being received
by the ≈øaid Earle, he with all ≈øpeed ≈øetled his affaires, and on Tue≈øday the 18. of this pre≈øent October he arrived in London, who≈øe welcome pre≈øence made ore-ioyed the hearts of his beholders the occa≈øion of his comming to towne as is generally conceived is to rai≈øe men in Kent and E≈ø≈øex, his Lord≈øhip being ≈øo highly beloved in tho≈øe parts, that he can ray≈øe more men for the defence of the King and Parliament, then any other Nobleman in the whole Kingdome.
On Wedne≈øday the 19ht. day of this moneth, the Major of Worce≈øter was brought to London, with a Waggon laden with Plate, which was taken from the malignants of that County.
